Add salt and about a cup of water. Let the bhaji simmer for 10-15 minutes, mashing occasionally, until it reaches a thick, cohesive consistency.
Finish with a large dollop of butter and chopped cilantro.
To serve, slit the pavs horizontally, smear with butter, and toast them on the tawa until lightly browned.
Serve the hot bhaji with the buttered pav, a lemon wedge, and some raw chopped onions.
notes: A generous amount of butter is key to the authentic taste.
The final texture of the bhaji should be a coarse mash, not a smooth puree.

recipes.name: Phirni
recipes.description: A classic, creamy North Indian pudding made with ground rice, milk, and sugar, set in small earthenware bowls (shikoras) and served chilled.
instructions: Wash and soak the basmati rice for at least 30 minutes. Drain and grind it into a coarse, grainy paste with a little milk or water.
In a heavy-bottomed pan, bring the milk to a boil.
Add the ground rice paste to the boiling milk, stirring continuously to prevent lumps from forming.
Reduce the heat and simmer, stirring frequently, for about 15-20 minutes, until the rice is cooked and the mixture has thickened considerably.
Add the sugar and saffron milk. Stir well until the sugar dissolves.
Continue to cook for another 5 minutes until the phirni is thick and creamy.
Turn off the heat and stir in the cardamom powder and rose water.
Pour the phirni into individual earthenware bowls. Garnish with slivered nuts.
Let it cool to room temperature, then refrigerate for at least 3-4 hours until well chilled and set.
Serve cold.
notes: Phirni is different from kheer in that it uses ground rice instead of whole rice, resulting in a smoother, pudding-like texture.
Setting it in earthenware bowls enhances the flavor and helps thicken it.

recipes.name: Pithe
recipes.description: A diverse category of homemade sweets from the eastern Indian states, especially Bengal, Assam, and Odisha, typically made from rice flour and having a sweet filling.

ingredients.name: For Shell: Rice flour or Semolina

instructions: This is a general recipe for a popular type, 'Doodh Puli Pithe'.
Prepare a filling by cooking grated coconut and jaggery until sticky.
Prepare a dough with rice flour and hot water. Knead until smooth.
Take a small portion of dough, flatten it, stuff with the filling, and seal it into a small dumpling shape (puli).
In a separate pot, bring milk to a boil. Add sugar or jaggery and cardamom.
Gently drop the prepared puli into the simmering sweet milk.
Cook on low heat for 10-15 minutes until the puli are cooked and the milk has thickened.
Serve warm or chilled.
notes: 'Pithe' is a broad term covering many varieties: some are steamed (bhapa pithe), some are fried (bhaja pithe), and some are cooked in milk or syrup (doodh puli, roshbora).

recipes.name: Poha
recipes.description: A popular and light breakfast dish from Western India, made from flattened rice (poha), sautéed with onions, potatoes, and spices.
instructions: Place the poha in a sieve and rinse it under running water for a minute. Let it drain completely. The poha will soften.
Heat oil in a pan. Add mustard seeds. When they crackle, add the peanuts and sauté until crisp. Add the curry leaves and green chilies.
Add the chopped onion (and potato, if using). Sauté until the onion is translucent and the potato is tender.
Add the turmeric powder and sauté for a few seconds.
Add the drained poha, salt, and sugar. Mix very gently to combine everything, being careful not to mash the poha.
Cover and cook on low heat for 2-3 minutes, allowing the poha to steam.
Turn off the heat. Squeeze the lemon juice over the poha and mix gently.
Garnish with fresh cilantro and a generous amount of sev. Serve immediately.
notes: Do not soak the poha in water, just rinse it. Soaking will make it mushy.
The dish should be light, fluffy, and non-sticky.

recipes.name: Poornalu
recipes.description: A traditional festive sweet from Andhra Pradesh, consisting of a sweet lentil-jaggery ball dipped in a rice-lentil batter and deep-fried.

ingredients.name: For Batter: Dosa batter or a mix of Urad dal and Rice flour

instructions: For the filling (poornam): Cook the soaked chana dal until soft but not mushy. Drain all the water.
Grind the dal into a paste. In a pan, cook this dal paste with jaggery and coconut until the mixture thickens and leaves the sides of the pan. Add cardamom powder. Let it cool.
Make small, tight balls from the cooled filling.
For the batter: Prepare a thick batter, similar to dosa batter but slightly thicker, by grinding soaked urad dal and rice.
Heat oil in a kadai.
Dip each filling ball into the batter, ensuring it's coated evenly.
Carefully drop the batter-coated balls into the hot oil. Fry on medium heat until they are golden brown and crisp.
Drain and serve warm.
notes: The filling should be dry and firm so that it's easy to shape into balls.
The batter should be thick enough to coat the filling balls properly without being too heavy.

recipes.name: Pootharekulu
recipes.description: A unique and delicate paper-thin sweet from Andhra Pradesh, made from a special rice starch batter, layered with powdered sugar and ghee.
instructions: This is a highly specialized sweet that is difficult to make at home without the right equipment and skill.
A special rice batter is made and fermented.
A terracotta pot is heated upside down over a fire.
A thin cloth is dipped into the batter and quickly wiped over the hot pot, creating a paper-thin, transparent film that cooks instantly.
This film is carefully peeled off. Two or three such films are layered.
Ghee is smeared over the layers, and a generous amount of powdered sugar (and nuts) is sprinkled.
The layered sheet is then folded neatly into a rectangle.
The final product is a crispy, flaky, and translucent sweet that melts in the mouth.
notes: The name 'Pootharekulu' translates to 'coated sheets'.
It's an art form passed down through generations in the villages of Andhra Pradesh, particularly Atreyapuram.

recipes.name: Qubani Ka Meetha
recipes.description: A classic Hyderabadi dessert made from dried apricots (qubani), cooked into a compote and often served with fresh cream, malai, or ice cream.
instructions: Wash the dried apricots and soak them in 3 cups of water overnight.
The next day, the apricots will be plump and soft. Deseed them, but reserve the kernels inside the seeds.
Crack open the seeds to get the apricot kernels. Blanch them to remove the skin.
In a pan, cook the soaked apricots along with their soaking water on medium heat until they become very soft and mushy.
Add the sugar and continue to cook, stirring, until the mixture thickens to a jam-like consistency.
Add the lemon juice and mix well. Turn off the heat.
Let the meetha cool down completely.
To serve, spoon the Qubani ka Meetha into serving bowls, top with a swirl of fresh cream or a dollop of malai, and garnish with the blanched apricot kernels and almonds.
notes: The apricot kernels have a nutty flavor similar to almonds and are the traditional garnish.
The amount of sugar depends on the sweetness of the apricots used.

recipes.name: Rabri
recipes.description: A rich, sweetened, and thickened milk dessert, made by slowly simmering milk until it reduces, collecting the layers of cream (malai) to create a lumpy, luscious texture.
instructions: Pour the milk into a wide, heavy-bottomed pan (kadai) and bring to a boil.
Reduce the heat to low and let it simmer. Do not stir the milk too often.
A layer of cream (malai) will form on the surface. Gently push this layer from the center to the sides of the pan.
Continue this process of simmering and collecting the cream on the sides until the milk is reduced to about one-third of its original volume.
Now, scrape all the collected cream layers from the sides and mix them back into the thickened milk. This gives rabri its characteristic texture.
Add sugar, saffron, and cardamom powder. Cook for another 5 minutes until the sugar dissolves.
Turn off the heat. The rabri will thicken more as it cools.
Garnish with slivered nuts. Serve chilled on its own, or as a topping for jalebi, malpua, or ghevar.
notes: This process requires patience. The key is to let the cream form and not to stir the milk constantly.
This is very similar to Basundi, but Rabri is generally thicker and has more prominent layers of cream.

recipes.name: Rasgulla
recipes.description: A famous Bengali sweet consisting of soft, spongy balls of chenna (Indian cottage cheese) cooked and soaked in a light sugar syrup.
instructions: Make chenna by curdling boiling milk with lemon juice. Strain it, rinse, and squeeze out all excess water.
Knead the chenna on a plate for 8-10 minutes with the heel of your palm until it is very smooth, soft, and non-greasy. Add flour/semolina if using.
Divide the smooth chenna into small, crack-free balls.
In a large, wide pot or pressure cooker, dissolve the sugar in water and bring it to a rolling boil.
Carefully drop the chenna balls into the boiling syrup.
Cover and cook on high heat for 15-20 minutes. The rasgullas will puff up and double in size.
Turn off the heat and let them cool completely in the syrup. Add rose water.
Refrigerate for a few hours before serving. Serve chilled.
notes: A well-kneaded, smooth chenna is the secret to spongy, non-breaking rasgullas.
The pot must be large enough to accommodate the expanded rasgullas.

recipes.name: Ras Malai
recipes.description: A luxurious Bengali dessert where soft, flattened chenna discs are cooked in sugar syrup and then soaked in a thickened, sweetened, and flavored milk (rabri).

ingredients.name: For Chenna discs: Milk, Lemon juice (as for rasgulla)
Saffron, Cardamom powder, slivered Pistachios & Almonds

instructions: First, prepare the chenna discs. Follow the Rasgulla recipe to make chenna, knead it, but shape it into small, flattened discs instead of balls.
Cook these discs in a light sugar syrup (1 cup sugar to 4 cups water) for 10-12 minutes until they puff up. Let them cool in the syrup.
While they cool, prepare the rabri. Boil 1 liter of milk and simmer it until it reduces to about two-thirds of its volume.
Add sugar, saffron, and cardamom powder to the reduced milk. Stir until sugar dissolves.
Gently squeeze the excess syrup from the cooled chenna discs and add them to the warm rabri.
Simmer for 5-7 minutes, allowing the discs to absorb the flavored milk.
Turn off the heat. Garnish with slivered nuts.
Chill thoroughly for at least 4-6 hours before serving.
notes: The chenna discs should be soft and spongy to absorb the rabri well.
The rabri for ras malai is typically thinner than the rabri served on its own.

recipes.name: Samosa
recipes.description: A crispy, deep-fried triangular pastry filled with a savory mixture of spiced potatoes and peas.
instructions: For the dough: In a bowl, mix flour, carom seeds, salt, and ghee. Rub until it resembles breadcrumbs. Add water gradually to form a stiff dough. Cover and rest for 30 minutes.
For the filling: Heat 1 tbsp oil in a pan. Add cumin seeds. Add mashed potatoes, peas, and all the powdered spices. Mix well and cook for 5 minutes. Let it cool.
Divide the dough into small balls. Roll each ball into an oval shape and cut it in half.
Take one half, form a cone, and stuff it with the potato filling. Seal the edges using a little water.
Heat oil in a wok or deep pan. Fry the samosas on low-medium heat until they are golden brown and crispy.
Serve hot with mint chutney or tamarind chutney.
notes: Frying on low heat is crucial for a crispy, non-bubbly crust.
The dough should be stiff, not soft like chapati dough.

recipes.name: Sandesh
recipes.description: A simple and elegant Bengali sweet made from fresh, finely kneaded chenna and powdered sugar, often flavored with cardamom or saffron.
instructions: Prepare fresh chenna, ensuring it is well-drained and has no excess moisture.
Place the chenna on a large plate and knead it with the heel of your palm for 8-10 minutes until it becomes completely smooth, creamy, and non-greasy.
Add the powdered sugar and cardamom powder to the kneaded chenna. Mix well.
Transfer this mixture to a non-stick pan. Cook on very low heat for 5-7 minutes, stirring continuously. The mixture will come together and start to leave the sides of the pan. Do not overcook.
Immediately transfer the mixture back to the plate and let it cool until it's just warm enough to handle.
Knead it again for a minute to make it smooth.
You can either shape it by hand into small patties or press it into sandesh molds to create decorative patterns.
Garnish with a pistachio sliver or a strand of saffron.
Refrigerate for an hour to let it set properly. Serve chilled.
notes: The key to a good sandesh is perfectly made chenna and thorough kneading.
Overcooking the chenna-sugar mixture will make the sandesh hard and chewy.

recipes.name: Shankarpali
recipes.description: A popular sweet or savory snack from Maharashtra, made by deep-frying small, diamond-shaped pieces of a flour dough.
instructions: In a bowl, mix the flour and cardamom powder.
In a separate pan, warm the milk/water, sugar, and ghee together until the sugar dissolves. Let it cool slightly.
Gradually add this liquid mixture to the flour and knead a stiff dough.
Cover and let the dough rest for 20-30 minutes.
Divide the dough into large balls. Roll out each ball into a thick chapati (about 1/4 inch thickness).
Using a knife or a pizza cutter, cut the rolled dough into diamond or square shapes.
Separate the pieces and keep them on a plate.
Heat oil in a kadai on medium-low heat. Fry the shankarpali in batches until they are golden brown and crisp.
Drain on a paper towel and let them cool completely.
Store in an airtight container.
notes: Frying on low heat ensures they cook evenly and become crispy.
For a savory version (namkeen shankarpali), replace sugar with salt, and add ajwain (carom seeds) and chili powder.

recipes.name: Sheera
recipes.description: A simple and comforting Indian pudding made from roasted semolina (sooji/rava), ghee, sugar, and water or milk, often served as prasad.
instructions: In a pan, heat the ghee. Add the cashews and roast until golden, then add the raisins and roast until they plump up. Remove and set aside.
In the same ghee, add the semolina. Roast on low heat, stirring continuously, for about 8-10 minutes, until it becomes fragrant and changes to a light golden color.
While the sooji is roasting, bring the water/milk to a boil in a separate pot.
Once the sooji is well-roasted, carefully and slowly pour the hot water/milk into the pan. Be cautious as it will splutter a lot. Stir continuously to avoid lumps.
The sooji will absorb the liquid quickly. Cover and cook on low heat for 2-3 minutes.
Add the sugar, cardamom powder, and roasted nuts and raisins. Mix well.
Cook for another 2-3 minutes until the sugar dissolves and the sheera leaves the sides of the pan.
Serve hot.
notes: Roasting the semolina properly is the key to a flavorful, non-sticky sheera.
This dish is also known as Suji ka Halwa.

recipes.name: Sheer Korma
recipes.description: A rich and festive vermicelli pudding, especially popular during Eid, made with fine vermicelli, milk, dates, sugar, and a variety of nuts.
instructions: In a pan, heat the ghee. Add all the slivered nuts and charoli. Sauté on low heat until they are lightly golden and fragrant. Remove and set aside.
In the same ghee, add the vermicelli and roast on low heat until it turns a deep golden brown. Be careful not to burn it.
Meanwhile, bring the milk to a boil in a separate, heavy-bottomed pot.
Add the roasted vermicelli to the boiling milk. Also add the chopped dates.
Simmer on low heat for 10-15 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the vermicelli is cooked and the milk has thickened slightly.
Add the sugar and stir until it dissolves. Cook for another 5 minutes.
Add most of the roasted nuts (reserving some for garnish), cardamom powder, and saffron.
Stir well and turn off the heat.
Serve warm or chilled, garnished with the remaining nuts.
notes: 'Sheer' means milk and 'Korma' means dates in Persian, indicating the key ingredients.
The consistency should be like a flowing, creamy pudding, not too thick.

recipes.name: Shrikhand
recipes.description: A simple yet elegant dessert from Western India, made from strained yogurt (chakka), sweetened with sugar, and flavored with cardamom and saffron.

ingredients.name: Saffron strands, soaked in 1 tbsp warm milk

instructions: Place the yogurt in a muslin or cheesecloth. Tie it up, hang it over a bowl, and let the whey drain out for at least 8-12 hours in the refrigerator. This will result in a thick, cheese-like mass called 'chakka' or hung curd.
Transfer the chakka to a bowl. It should be very thick.
Add the powdered sugar, saffron-infused milk, and cardamom powder.
Whisk everything together vigorously until the mixture is very smooth, creamy, and light. You can also pass it through a fine-mesh sieve to get an even smoother texture.
Stir in most of the slivered nuts.
Transfer the shrikhand to a serving bowl.
Chill in the refrigerator for at least 1-2 hours.
Serve cold, garnished with the remaining nuts.
notes: Straining the yogurt properly is the most important step to get the right consistency.
For 'Amrakhand' (mango shrikhand), add 1 cup of thick mango pulp to the mixture.

recipes.name: Sohan Halwa
recipes.description: A traditional, dense, and nutty sweet confection, typically sold as a disc, made from germinated wheat, milk, sugar, and ghee.
instructions: Sprout the whole wheat by soaking and then tying it in a damp cloth for 2-3 days. Grind the sprouts to a fine paste.
In a large, heavy-bottomed pan, mix the wheat sprout paste, maida, and milk. Cook on low heat, stirring continuously.
The milk will start to curdle and the mixture will thicken.
Once it becomes a thick mass, add the sugar and continue to cook, stirring constantly.
Begin adding ghee, a little at a time, and keep cooking and stirring. The mixture will start to change color and become glossy.
Cook until it turns a deep brown color and starts to leave the sides of the pan, and the ghee separates.
Add saffron, cardamom, and nuts.
Pour into a greased thali or pan. Let it set completely.
Cut into pieces or serve as a whole disc.
notes: This is a very traditional and time-consuming recipe. The process is key to its unique flavor and texture.
Modern, quicker versions often use corn flour and milk powder.

recipes.name: Sohan Papdi
recipes.description: A popular, super-flaky, and crisp North Indian sweet with a melt-in-the-mouth texture, often sold in cubes or as loose threads.
instructions: This is a complex sweet that requires practice and preferably two people.
Roast the besan and maida in ghee until a nutty aroma arises. Keep this mixture warm.
In a separate pan, prepare a sugar syrup with sugar, water, and lemon juice. Cook it until it reaches a hard ball consistency (250°F / 120°C on a candy thermometer).
Pour the hot sugar syrup into the warm flour-ghee mixture. Mix quickly.

This next step involves pulling and folding the mixture repeatedly to create the flaky threads. Pour the mixture onto a greased surface. Using handles of wooden spoons or spatulas, lift, pull, and fold the mixture back on itself dozens of times until it forms fine, silky threads.
Press the flaky mixture into a greased tray, garnish with nuts and cardamom, and press down firmly.
Let it set for 30 minutes, then cut into squares.
notes: The process of pulling the sugar is what creates the iconic flaky texture and is very difficult to master.
The temperature of the sugar syrup is critical.

recipes.name: Sutar Feni
recipes.description: A delicate and thread-like Rajasthani sweet, resembling fine vermicelli, made by stretching a special dough multiple times, which is then fried and often served with sweetened milk (rabri).
instructions: Making Sutar Feni is an extremely skillful and complex process, similar to making hand-pulled noodles.
A soft dough is made from maida and water.
A paste is made from ghee and corn flour (this is called 'sata').
The dough is rolled out, smeared with sata, folded, and rolled again. This is repeated several times.
The prepared dough is then stretched by hand, looped, and stretched again, repeatedly, to create thousands of extremely fine threads.
This bundle of threads is then gently shaped into a nest and deep-fried in ghee on low heat until crisp.
It is then garnished with powdered sugar and nuts, or soaked in sugar syrup.
Often served with a side of rabri.
notes: This is a specialty sweet that is almost exclusively made by professional confectioners (halwais) due to the skill involved.
It is very light, flaky, and delicate.

recipes.name: Unni Appam
recipes.description: A small, round, sweet fritter from Kerala, made from a batter of rice flour, jaggery, banana, and coconut, fried in a special molded pan (appakara).

ingredients.name: Coconut pieces (thenga kothu), fried in ghee

instructions: Melt the jaggery with a little water to create a thick syrup. Strain it to remove impurities and let it cool.
In a bowl, mix the rice flour, mashed banana, cardamom powder, and baking soda.
Gradually add the cooled jaggery syrup to the flour mixture to make a thick batter, similar to idli batter consistency.
Stir in the ghee-fried coconut pieces.
Cover and let the batter rest for at least 4-5 hours.
Heat an appam pan (aebleskiver pan) and fill each mold halfway with ghee or coconut oil.
When the oil is hot, pour the batter into each mold.
Cook on medium-low heat until the bottom is dark brown and the top is cooked.
Flip each appam and cook the other side until it is also dark brown and crisp.
Drain and serve warm.
notes: The batter resting time is important for the flavors to develop and for fermentation.
The combination of banana, jaggery, and coconut gives it a unique and delicious flavor.
